results.notes:
A NJMA foray collection.
This one was the largest and freshest of a large number of fruiting bodies of this species brought back from the woods by foray participants.
This is not L. scabrum on account of the bluing action of the exposed flesh. I think this is the same taxon represented by several observations of mine from last year, e.g., obs 281644, obs 287648, and obs 288622 (the last one also from Stokes S.F.).
This species is distinguished from other similar-looking taxa in NJ by its light to medium brown color of the cap, a network of darker brown to blackish fibrils on the cap surface, bluing of the flesh that is restricted to the lower half of stipe, and a very slow oxidation of the cap context to pale brown.
DNA Results and Discussion (posted 22-Jul-19; content last edited 9-May-20):
Results:
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. It consists of the full-length nrITS sequence of 1138 bps, followed by the first 311 bps of the nrLSU locus. Like it is the case with genus Leccinum as a whole, the ITS1 region in this organism is much longer in comparison with other members of the Boletaceae, 666 nucleotides to be exact. The highly conserved 5.8S sublocus is of the standard length of 161 bps. This makes ITS2 311 bps long.
> A BLASTn search of the full-length ITS sequence gave three perfectly matching hits:
MH571415: Leccinum flavostipitatum voucher MEN-MB-10801 from Massachusetts (the first 786 bps, no ITS2)
MH571412: Leccinum scabrum voucher MB-06026 from Massachusetts (the first 857 bps, no ITS2)
MH571413 Leccinum sp. voucher MB-06040 from New York (the first 857 bps, no ITS2)
> Since the ITS1 sublocus in Leccinum is useless for phylogenetic analyses (even at the intra-sectional level) due to variable length mini-satellite DNA repeats causing complicated patterns of insertions/deletions,1,2 I turned my attention toward the 5.8S-ITS2 region of the locus. A BLASTn of the 5.8S-ITS2 sequence fragment gave a hit list from which carefully curated accessions of mostly named European taxa were chosen based on the common overlay length, identification confidence, and their inclusion in the den Bakker & Noorderloos study (Ref. 2). After some experimentation with the accession selection, the desired tree topology consisting of well-defined species and/or species group clades was achieved and posted to this observation (Fig. 1).3 As can be seen from the tree, MO330112 clades in a group of 6 North American accessions identified as Leccinum snellii or cf. snellii by notable professional mycologists (T.D. Bruns, R.E. Halling, A.H. Smith, J.L. Frank):
AY853546: Leccinum snellii clone 107/voucher tdb.1234.0 (from VA)2
AY853547: Leccinum snellii clone 108/voucher tdb.1234.1 (from VA)2
AY538845: Leccinum cf. snellii voucher Halling 4472 (from NY)2
AY538846: Leccinum cf. snellii voucher Halling 6914 (from NC)2
AY853545: Leccinum snellii clone t18/voucher Smith 72119 (from MI)2
MK033965: Leccinum sp. voucher JLF5584 (from VT)
> A BLASTn of the 311 bps nrLSU fragment showed it to be 100% identical to MH238505 associated with my voucher of L. snellii, obs 288473.

Discussion:
> The ITS1 sequence of MO330112 is identical to three GenBank accessions bearing non-matching identifications to species. To complicate the matters, these GB sequences unfortunately lack the ITS2 sublocus. However, despite this latter shortcoming, two important conclusions can be readily drawn at this time: (a) this species has a very stable ITS1 region, not affected by the occasional intraspecific variation present in the mini-satellite motifs within this sublocus, that can act as a reliable genetic barcode and (b) this taxon is not conspecific with any of the known European scaber stalks from sect. Scabra, for which GenBank accessions derived from properly identified vouchers exist. With the regard to the second point, this scaber stalk appears to be exclusively endemic to North America.
As to the phylogeny derived from the 5.8-ITS2 BLASTn, MO330112 is shown to clade in what I believe is the “snellii group”. In order to better understand this phylogenetic clade and the relationships between its constituents, their sequences were aligned in MUSCLE (see Fig. 2).4 Analysis of these data reveals two species potentially present in this group. While the ITS2 sequence of MO330112 perfectly matches two GenBank accessions derived from the material collected by T.D. Bruns in VA, the other four GB accessions – that are essentially identical to each other – all contain two notable indels relative to MO330112. Importantly, this latter group includes A.H. Smith’s L. snelii HOLOTYPE voucher from Michigan (AY853545). One of the indels, TGCGTG, is very unique, whereas the other one is part of the long homopolymeric “A”-motif. Both indels are real because their respective lengths are conserved across the four GB accessions.
An argument perhaps can be made that the two indels represent an ancestral polymorphism seen in a single species.5 However, the ITS1 regions of MO330112 and J.L. Frank’s MK033965 (the only GB accession in this GB selection featuring an ITS1 sequence!), are unquestionably different (see Fig. 3).6 This strongly supports the earlier notion that there are, indeed, more than one OTU in this “clade”.
> Yet another pertinent piece of evidence comes from the LSU locus. A BLASTn of the nrLSU sequence of my L. snellii (obs 288473; MH238505), gave the following high-value hits, with 99.4-99.9% similarity and 82-94% query cover (sorted by decreasing % similarity):
AF139696: Leccinum flavostipitatum strain 24/98 (from USA)
EU522789: Leccinum aff. flavostipitatum TM02_71 (from Canada)
JQ327007: Leccinum sp. voucher MB06-040 (from NY)
AY612814: Leccinum scabrum voucher NCJ26 (from USA)
MH620342: Leccinum flavostipitatum voucher MB10801 (from MA)
MH620341: Leccinum scabrum voucher MB-06026 (from MA)
MF797699: Leccinum sp. strain NJJ14_090B (from TN)
Note that none of the above vouchers are identified as snellii, probably because they didn’t look like it. Also recall that the 3 bolded vouchers and MO330112 have identical ITS1 sequences. Alignment of these 7 accessions together with the LSU of snellii/MO288473 shows that the common overlay differs at seven (7) positions. Five (5) of these sites may not be significant because at each of these positions 7 of 8 vouchers have a matching character. For example, the 194th character is a “C”, while MF797699 has a gap there, and the 735th character is a “C”, while my NJ snellii has a “T” there (possibly a fully polymorphic site, i.e., C/T/Y). The remaining two positions (332nd and 931st characters) may be significant. Accessions JQ327007, MH620341, MH620342, and MF797699 have a “T” and a “G”, respectively, whereas accessions AF139696, AY612814, EU522789, and MH238505 (snellii) have a “C” and an “A”, respectively. Note that 3 out of 4 accessions in the first group belong to vouchers having identical ITS1 sequences to that of MO330112.
Given that LSU is known to have a generally mediocre barcoding gap, it would not be surprising that closely related species may have very similar or even identical sequences. If we are dealing with a single species, however, the few observed differences may well represent a natural range of single-point mutations seen across different populations in a wide geographical area. Regardless of the actual scenario, this locus is certainly not a useful genetic marker for drawing solid inferences.

Conclusion:
A thorough analysis of the ITS data points to the existence of a “Leccinum snellii group” and suggests that MO330112 may not be Leccinum snellii. The taxon this observation represents is likely common and widespread in eastern North America, where birch is present. L. snellii, described by Smith et al. from Michigan, is in part characterized by the exposed flesh staining both red and blue, whereas the flesh of MO330112 stains only blue at the base of stipe. Additional collections of this species from the same geographic region (northwestern NJ) are represented by obs 281664 and obs 288622 (MycoFlora sequencing; identical ITS1). They also show lack of flesh reddening and the bluing being restricted to stipe base.
Further research will involve procuring LSU from MO330112 and sampling obs 370555 for ITS/LSU.
References & Notes:
1 Den Bakker et al., “An ITS phylogeny of Leccinum and an analysis of the evolution of minisatellite-like sequences within ITS”; Mycologia 2004, term 96(1), pp. 102-118
2 Den Bakker et al., “Phylogeographic pattersn in Leccinum sect. Scabra and the status of the arctic-alpine species L. rotundifoliae”; Mycological Research 2007, term 111, pp. 663-672
3 Regardless of the overall tree topology, MO330112 always claded within the same group of accessions
4 The ITS2 region is located between the purple (end of 5.8S) and red (beginning of nrLSU) highlights
5 Den Bakker et al., “Evolution and host specificity in the ectomycorrhizal genus Leccinum”; New Phytologist 2004, term 163, pp. 201-215
6 The red highlights at the beginning and end of the overlay are the end and start of nrSSU & nrLSU loci, respectively; the termini of the 5.8S sublocus within ITS are highlighted in magenta

results.notes:
Habitat: Under oak trees
Substrate: Lawn
Abundance: Quite a Few
Cap, context, tubes and stipe do not stain on cutting or bruising. Tubes are white on young specimens, yellow in older specimens. Odor and taste are not distinctive. Reticulation on stipe is white and increasing coarse near the base of the stipe.

There a some characters that don’t fit the description in Bessette et al. For example, the reticulation is white rather than brown. The stipe is greatly enlarged, rather than “slightly enlarged” downward.

ITS sequence is 99% match with a B. atkinsonii specimen (MH281863) from Florida submitted by Kaminsky,B.S., Smith,M.E., Healy,R. and Spakes Richter,B., but also a 99% match with sequences for several specimens identified as Tylopilus sp.

results.notes:
Two off-white mushrooms, with light brown centers. Cap of smaller mushroom convex to slightly nobbed, smooth, ~ 20 mm diameter. Margin appears serrated where it is upturned, but only because the upturning makes the gill structure visible. The larger individual is “past its prime”. Its cap is heart-shaped as an artifact of deterioration which has caused its margin to become severely, irregularly upturned and has created a large radial tear; its average diameter is ~ 45 mm. Stems creamy white, cylindrical (equal), thin, 3-4 mm diameter, 50-70 mm tall. Gills off-white, adnate, close.

Observed growing in a common area lawn of a suburban neighborhood on an insular tropical upland plateau.

I found this on an old square hay bale in the woods. I let it print overnight but it didn’t appear to leave a print. I didn’t think to add something for scale in the pictures but it was pretty small. The cap was no bigger than 1/2". The middle of the stem got a little messed up, but the bottom of the stem seemed to turn blue.

The other mushroom was found in the same spot a month later. I wasn’t able to get a print from that one either.

results.notes:
On a lawn with Norway spruce. According to Kerrigan, Agaricus mushrooms representing section Arvenses and found in grassy areas under Norway spruce are likely to be A. arvensis.

Cap surface bruising yellow in spots. Arc across larger cap surface 3.5-4 inches.

Estimated spore dimensions 5.5-7 × 4.5-5, which agrees with Pennsylvania arvensis as reported in Agaricus of North America. Spores obtained from spore drop.

The one thing that fails to match arvensis is that the partial veil seen on the larger mushroom has not formed a pendant annulus. Instead there is only a small thin portion adhering to the stipe, with most of the velar material pulling away from the stipe and seeming to adhere to the cap margin. However, the “cogwheel” pattern (partial) can be breaking apart. The smaller mushroom failed to expand.

results.location_name: Scripps Ranch, San Diego, San Diego Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Two photos show the mushroom early during the first day it appeared. The second photo was taken about 24 hours later. Weather was dry throughout this 24 hour period, but the ground was quite moist from heavy rains leading up to this time period.

First photo accurately shows the young mushroom with a dark disc. Post mature mushroom exhibits the mono-color gray cap associated with A. rooseveltensis.

Throughout the summer many of these modestly-sized gray grisettes occur in one flush after another in each of two different spots on my property. Habitat is mowed lawn with shagbark hickory. No oak in the particular spot where the mushroom seen in this observation was found. (Some small oaks near the other spot.) Some of these mushrooms have fairly dark caps, most notably on the disc (and especially when young), and some are more uniformly gray throughout the entire fruiting cycle. As seen in this observation, the dark cap color may fade. The typical “life span” of one of these mushrooms appears to be quite short. This one went from button to well past maturity (no spore drop) in little more than 24 hours.

results.notes:
This mushroom was too decomposed to be of value as a preserved specimen. But, it’s interesting because…

The large size (5cm < cap < 6cm; 12cm < stipe < 13cm), cap with dark disc, and location all give cause to consider A. luzernensis. The prominently zonate pigmentation of the cap seen in obs 74501 is missing from this presently considered example. But, it’s not difficult to believe that this feature was lessened due to fading.

This was found on the same oak-dominated south-facing ridge as 74501. I have been checking this ridge over the years, hoping to gain insight into A. luzernensis. For one, I had hoped to gain more specific information regarding the types of trees in the immediate habitat. Recently, an example suspected to represent luzernensis was collected in Letchworth State Park, NY for which hemlock was listed as a tree found in the vicinity of the mushroom. Regarding the trees nearby this present observation, the spot featured both oak and hemlock.

Spore dimensions for this present observation well match 74501, mainly globose with wide range in diameter, 7-11 microns.

I checked this ridge at least 6 times over the course of this summer. Apparently, the one week when I was too busy to check is when this mushroom had fruited. The weather here continues to be hot with showers in the forecast. Maybe there will be another chance.

results.notes:
Oak-dominated woods.

The context in the cap is very pale yellow, as opposed to what appears in the photo to be white.

Spores 8-11 × 3-4.

I suspect these are B. bicolor that had remained in situ for an extended period, during which time the unusual ribbed/subreticulate ornamentation developed. The white coating on the stipe base may be the beginning stages of a Hypomyces, and this could account for the unusual reddish areas of context inside the stipe.

Or, maybe it’s something other than bicolor? Many examples of typical bicolor have been observed in this spot.

results.notes: These Bovista plumbea mushrooms were found in the Pacific Northwest in Pullman, Washington in a grassy field. They are there year round, and can be recognized as “brown, spore-filled mushrooms.” When these mushrooms (shown in pictures) were collected, it was January 26, 2018. There was light snow, but the mushrooms were still on the ground. The mushrooms seem to appear most around Spring and Fall. There are still scattered ones around Summer and Winter, but fewer mushrooms than those in the other seasons. They are odorless and as far as we know, non-toxic. They have not been seen growing on trees, but on the ground.

325210 nearby area is covered with this, literally hundreds. Most of them grow quite tall (10cm). I’ve seen a lot of earth tongues for the last few months. Usually near what I call swampy area. According to Wikipedia, Michigan has 64,980 inland lakes and ponds. Almost all the park trials I’ve been either circle the lakes or near the lakes. This kind of swampy area is covered with water in the early spring. Then mostly dry up during the summer. I rarely approach swampy area for its mosquitos-promising. Maybe that’s the reason, I haven’t really seen earth tongues in the past years.

results.notes:
In the past I found at this location several specimens, growing on calcareous rocks, similar to those considered here (see e.g. observations 270919, 274082, 274086), but i never succceed to observe one under the scope. This time I found again several specimens and made the microscopy of one.
I think that the species sought is more like Opegrapha (than Arthonia, the genus that I thought to apply): The asci are elongated, react blue in tholus. The spores are consistently 3-sepatate. I didn´t found a convenient species in the literarature I have and on the website visited. The morphologic features are not very usual: lirellae immersed and completely pruinose concolor with the white thallus.

My first sighting of what I think are kings. But I’m not sure of my ID and would welcome feedback. Several specimens closely associated with sugar maples (growing at root bases). Slugs in cap and stems.
Large with pale brown velvety cap, white context, buff white tubes turning slightly pink/mauve. Pores small, < 0.5 mm, bruising yellow/brown with rough abrasion. No staining on cap or context. Stem firm, somewhat fibrous, pale cream to buff with clear reticulum and longitudinally elongate lacunae. Taste mild; odour nondescript.
A few otherwise identical mushrooms with darker brown caps found in the area.

results.notes:
This observation refers to the parasite of the Ramalina in the photos (R. lacera I believe). It is similar to Opegrapha physciaria considered at Observation 274049.
I tried the identification but was almost painfull, since the driver associated to the program for microscopy has a malfunction.
Let me add that:
- an apothecial section is similar to that of an Opegrapha
- It react KOH+ red but that reqction was very ephemeral;
- The spores are 3 (-4) septate; became brown when old;
- The tholus of the asci reacts IKI blue.
It also deserves mention that there is probable another parasite envolved that produces conidia (see the last set of photos attached).
